question: Question_03_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Short-Answer Questions}. Question 1-3 are short-answer
questions. Put your answer in the box provided. \textbf{Simplify your
answer as much as possible}. Full Marks will be awarded for a correct
answer placed in the box. \textbf{Show your work}, for part marks.

A force of 10 N (newtons) is required to hold a spring stretched 5 cm
beyond its natural length. How much work, in joules (J), is done in
stretching the spring from its natural length to 50 cm beyond its
natural length?
sols:
Recall for springs,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle 
f(x) = kx\end{align*}

We are given that force is 10 N when $x$ is 5 cm = 0.05 m, so

\begin{align*}\displaystyle 
10 = k(0.05)\end{align*}

giving $\displaystyle k = 200$. Then, the work done in stretching the
spring from its natural length to 50 cm = 0.5 m beyond its natural
length is given by

\begin{align*}
W &= \int_0^{0.5} 200x \ dx \\
&= 200 \frac{x^2}2 \big|_0^{0.5} \\
&= 25\end{align*}

So the work done in stretching the spring is 25J.
hints: Remember that force is $kx$ for a spring. But what is $k$ here?
